text: Layers of chromite, interbedded with other heavy minerals, are mined from such deposits in the Stillwater Complex of Montana.
Another example is the Bushveld Complex in South Africa, which contains over 70 percent of the world’s known reserves of platinum.
For example, as a large magma body cools, the heavy minerals that crystallize early tend to settle to the lower portion of the magma chamber (crystal settling).
This type of magmatic differentiation (see page 126) is particularly active in large basaltic magmas where chromite (ore of chromium), magnetite, and platinum are occasionally generated.
The igneous processes that generate some metal deposits are quite straightforward.
